page.title: 03Chickney,landscape/buildings
page.content: This is mainly undulating farmland with small woods and streams. The source of the River Chelmar, close to that of the Cam, can be traced, also a tributary, the Starr Brook. There are several ponds, fed by springs, 2 moated houses and reservoirs excavated probably since the drought of 1976. ChickneySt Mary's Church contains traces of pre-conquest work. One of the ancient windows is in the north wall of the nave. The church was extended in the 13th, 14th & 15th centuries. It was struck by lightening in 1902 and restored. The churchyard is listed as a site of special scientific interest on account of its rare wild flowers. Horham Hall built 1502-60 incorperating part of a half timbered house dating from 1476, it was restored 1840-50 & in 1976. Queen Elizabeth 1 stayed here in 1571 & 1578
